title: Trump's Plan to Save TikTok Amid Service Restoration in the US
summary:
- TikTok is restoring its service in the US after a temporary suspension due to legal threats.
- The restoration is backed by President Trump's clarification that no penalties will be levied on service providers.
- The app was previously unavailable on Apple and Google Play stores before this announcement.
- Trump proposed a joint venture that would give the US government a 50% ownership stake in TikTok, raising First Amendment concerns.
- At a rally, Trump credited TikTok for attracting young voters and emphasized the importance of keeping jobs in the US, rather than allowing profits to go to China.

sources.title: TikTok is restoring service in the US
Trump touts his plan to save TikTok during his victory rally

title: KKR hires Goldman to sell stake in PH fintech Maya: sources
summary:

- KKR owns over 20% of Maya, which could be valued at more than US$2 billion.
- KKR initially invested in Maya in October 2018 during a US$175 million funding round alongside Tencent Holdings.
- In April 2022, Maya raised US$210 million, achieving a valuation of US$1.4 billion for its digital banking services.

title: VPN interest rises amid US TikTok ban

title: TikTok is back, but where are Marvel Snap, CapCut, and Lemon8?
summary:
- TikTok has partially returned in the US after a nationwide ban, while Marvel Snap, CapCut, and Lemon8 remain blocked.
- Users attempting to access these apps see messages indicating they are banned.
- The ban on these apps follows a federal divest-or-ban law that took effect on January 19th, 2025.
- Both Google Play Store and Apple App Store prevent downloads for these apps due to legal restrictions.
- Uncertainty remains regarding when these apps will be available again.

sources.title: TikTok is back, but where are Marvel Snap, CapCut, and Lemon8?

title: TikTok’s Service Providers Face Billions in Penalties Amid Ongoing Ban
summary:
- TikTok is working to restore service but remains unavailable on the [App Store](https://www.theverge.com/2025/1/19/24347340/tiktok-ban-app-store-google-play) and Google Play.
- Users see a message indicating TikTok is not available in their region, with downloads paused due to US legal requirements.
- Some US users have regained access due to President Trump's efforts, though companies involved have not commented further.
- President-elect Trump cannot extend TikTok's ban deadline without risking penalties for service providers.
- TikTok remains banned until sold to a non-Chinese company; potential fines for providers like Apple and Google could reach $850 billion.
- Trump's assurances may not shield companies from legal repercussions; enforcement by the Supreme Court could happen up to five years later.

title: From recruiting for Palantir to landing a plane on Highway 85: meet defense tech’s wildest power broker
summary:

- He has worked with companies like Palantir, Mach Industries, and currently heads talent at venture firm A*.
- Conway is known for unconventional recruiting methods, including offering flights in his private plane and sharing fascinating personal stories.

title: AI Benchmarking Organization Criticized for Delayed Disclosure of OpenAI Funding
summary:
- Epoch AI, a nonprofit, revealed on December 20 its funding from OpenAI for the FrontierMath benchmark.
- Allegations of non-transparency arose as many contributors were unaware of OpenAI's involvement until public disclosure.
- Epoch AI admitted to communication failures but asserted that the benchmark's integrity remained intact despite OpenAI's access to problem sets.
- Associate director Tamay Besiroglu acknowledged a mistake in transparency and emphasized the importance of disclosing funding sources to contributors.
- Concerns about the potential impact on FrontierMath's reputation as an objective benchmark were raised on social media.

title: TikTok is restoring service in the US after brief shutdown
summary:
- TikTok is "in the process of restoring service" in the US after a half-day shutdown.
- The interruption aligned with a federal ban on the app.
- The company thanked President Trump for clarity allowing it to support over 170 million Americans and 7 million small businesses.
- Users can access TikTok via mobile and desktop web, but the app is unavailable on app stores.
- The shutdown was due to an impending federal ban, with a change in enforcement under the Biden administration.
- The service resumption happened after over 12 hours offline.
- Trump's executive order delayed a law that could have banned the app.
- TikTok's app temporarily disappeared from stores but returned for some users by the announcement.
- Trump proposed a potential joint venture for US ownership of TikTok.

title: TikTok and Marvel Snap Banned in the US Due to New Legislation
summary:
- Marvel Snap, linked to ByteDance, has been banned alongside TikTok due to new U.S. laws.
- Players lost access to the game on January 19, 2025, with announcements of an ongoing effort to restore it.
- Second Dinner, the game's developer, expressed surprise over the ban and ensured players that they are working to resolve the issue.
- The app has disappeared from iOS and Android platforms, while some PC players report issues logging in.
- Other apps from ByteDance also faced similar bans, expanding the impact beyond just Marvel Snap.

- TikTok has been banned in the U.S. due to a federal law, and users started receiving notifications around 10:30 p.m. Eastern on Saturday.
- The app is no longer available in the Apple and Google Play stores, with TikTok stating, "Sorry, TikTok isn’t available right now."
- TikTok is hopeful for a resolution with President-elect Trump indicating he will work towards reinstating it, urging users to stay tuned.
- The law requiring TikTok’s owner ByteDance to sell the app or face a ban was passed by bipartisan majorities in Congress and signed by President Biden last April.
- TikTok indicated it could go dark if no definitive statement was made by the Biden administration, which responded by calling TikTok’s actions a stunt.
- Trump has suggested he may delay the ban and negotiate terms possibly involving a sale or partnership, creating uncertainty around TikTok’s long-term future.

sources.title: Marvel Snap is banned, just like TikTok
TikTok goes dark in the US

title: Trump Proposes Delay of TikTok Ban with Joint Venture Plan
summary:
- President-elect Donald Trump proposes a joint venture for TikTok, aiming for the US to own 50% of the app.
- Trump intends to issue an executive order to delay the TikTok ban to protect national security.
- Republican lawmakers express skepticism about halting the TikTok ban without a legitimate sale to eliminate foreign ownership.
- TikTok went dark in the US on Saturday but may return soon.
- Bipartisan legislation requires ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban.
- The Supreme Court upheld the law before Trump’s inauguration.
- TikTok indicated a need for clarity before continuing operations; Trump aims to resume the app's functionality before the order is issued.

sources.title: Trump says he’ll delay TikTok ban, but the platform must be sold

title: The TikTok shutdown is locking out non-US users, too
summary:
- TikTok's US shutdown affects non-US users, with complaints of access issues from users in other countries.
- Some users on Reddit identified that using a VPN routing through the US caused access problems, while others claimed issues despite not using a VPN.
- Users from various countries including Canada, Germany, Australia, Greece, and Poland report being locked out, raising questions about TikTok's response to account creation locations and region settings.

sources.title: The TikTok shutdown is locking out non-US users, too

title: Employees of Failed Startups Face Increased Risk of Data Theft via Old Google Logins
summary:
- Security researcher Dylan Ayrey highlighted the risk of stolen personal data for employees of failed startups due to a Google OAuth vulnerability.
- Malicious hackers can acquire defunct domains and use them to access cloud software tied to former employees, potentially gaining access to sensitive information such as Social Security numbers.
- Ayrey tested the vulnerability by purchasing a failed startup's domain and accessing various software platforms including ChatGPT, Slack, and an HR system with sensitive data.
- Google initially dismissed the issue but later reopened the bug report and acknowledged the risk after Ayrey's talk at ShmooCon, awarding him a $1,337 bounty.

sources.title: Employees of Failed Startups Face Increased Risk of Data Theft via Old Google Logins

title: AI isn’t very good at history, new paper finds
summary:
- A new paper reveals that AI struggles with high-level history exams, specifically tested on GPT-4, Meta’s Llama, and Google’s Gemini.
- The benchmark, Hist-LLM, uses the Seshat Global History Databank for accuracy assessment, with GPT-4 Turbo scoring only 46%.
- Researchers note LLMs lack depth in historical understanding and are biased towards more prominent historical data, affecting their performance on nuanced questions.

sources.title: AI isn’t very good at history, new paper finds

title: Who banned TikTok? Politicians toss culpability like a football + The Supreme Court's Decision on TikTok and Its Impact on Users
summary:
- Users of the Chinese social media app [RedNote](https://www.fastcompany.com/91260771/5-things-to-know-about-tiktok-replacement-rednote) welcomed 'TikTok refugees' from the U.S. with selfies and messages.
- Over 700,000 new users joined RedNote due to a looming U.S. ban on TikTok, which has 170 million American users.
- The Supreme Court upheld a law requiring TikTok’s parent company, ByteDance, to sell the app or face a ban in two days.
- The US government banned TikTok on January 19, 2025, citing concerns over Chinese influence and data collection.
- The Protecting Americans From Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act was signed in April 2025 by President Biden, enabling the ban.
- Trump initiated the original ban in 2020 but now expresses intentions to permit the app under American ownership and may reverse the ban shortly after taking office.

title: The tech to build the holodeck
summary:
- Gaussian splatting is a new 3D capture method revolutionizing tech industry applications.
- Developed in 2023, it uses fuzzy, translucent blobs to create detailed, photorealistic 3D objects.
- Companies like Niantic, Google, and Meta are integrating Gaussian splatting into their products, enhancing AR and VR experiences.
- Niantic aims to democratize 3D capture with their Scaniverse app, facilitating the creation of a 3D map of the world.
- Meta's Hyperscape demo showcases photorealistic environments for exploratory experiences in VR.
- The technology allows for more creative flexibility in 3D video capture, even in low-light conditions.
- Future advancements may combine Gaussian splatting with generative AI to simplify and enhance the capture process.

title: Trump Considers Delay on TikTok Ban Amid Industry Concerns
summary:
- TikTok is crucial for music promotion, with about 40% of marketing agencies relying on it for campaigns.
- The US Supreme Court is deciding on a potential ban for TikTok over national security concerns.
- TikTok has transformed how artists rise to fame, with several recent hits propelled by the platform.
- A US ban could drastically disrupt the music industry as TikTok serves as a major influencer for trends on Spotify globally.
- Marketers advise artists to diversify their platforms and not rely solely on TikTok.
- Alternatives like Xiaohongshu pose challenges for music promotion due to limited sound libraries.
- Some in the industry hope for a creative renaissance away from the algorithmic pressures of TikTok.
- Donald Trump is considering suspending a TikTok ban in the US with an executive order upon entering office on January 20.
- He is exploring delaying enforcement of a sale-or-ban law that takes effect on January 19, which requires TikTok's US operations to be sold.
- TikTok plans to shut down for US users unless the Supreme Court intervenes; a decision on the law's validity is pending.
- Trump expressed a favorable view of TikTok and previously asked the Supreme Court to pause the ban for a political resolution.
- The Biden administration is reportedly looking into keeping TikTok operational beyond the deadline to allow Trump to make decisions.
- Shares of rival Snap fell as market speculation grew about TikTok's potential reprieve.

sources.title: Panic Grips US Music Industry as TikTok Faces Ban

title: Cringing before the tech giants is no way to make Britain an AI superpower
summary:
- Sir Keir Starmer delivered a speech on AI at University College London, calling it the defining opportunity of our generation.
- He announced a 50-point AI Opportunities Action Plan designed by Matt Clifford, emphasizing Britain's potential as an AI superpower.
- Concerns raised about Clifford's influence due to his prior wealth from tech investments and the risks of tech firms violating copyright.
- The Creative Rights in AI Coalition criticized claims of uncertainty in the UK text- and data-mining regime, asserting copyright laws are clear.
- The plan includes building national computing infrastructure, increasing university research capacity, and training AI professionals, which may be costly.
- There is a need for the UK government to engage more effectively with giant tech corporations and not adopt a servile approach.
- Economic experts suggest the general economic impact of AI may be smaller than anticipated in the short term, indicating that becoming an AI superpower will take time.

title: China Denies Data Violations Amid TikTok Concerns and Lawsuits
summary:
- Austrian advocacy group Noyb filed complaints on Jan. 16 against six Chinese companies for unlawful EU user data transfers to China.
- Companies involved include TikTok, AliExpress, Shein, Xiaomi, Temu, and WeChat.
- Noyb claims TikTok, Shein, Xiaomi, and AliExpress acknowledge sending user data to China, while Temu and WeChat send it to unnamed 'third countries'.
- Under the EU's GDPR, data transfers outside the EU are permissible only if the recipient country meets EU data protection standards, which Noyb argues China does not.
- The Chinese government asserts it has never compelled data collection in violation of the law.
- This statement was made by a foreign ministry spokesperson on January 17.
- The response follows a complaint from the Austrian group Noyb against six Chinese companies, including TikTok, for unlawfully transferring EU user data to China.

sources.title: TikTok, Shein, others sued over unlawful data transfers to China

title: TikTok Banned in the US as Users Look for Alternatives
summary:
- Average TikTok user spends nearly [one hour each day](https://www.oberlo.com/statistics/average-time-spent-on-tiktok).
- US Supreme Court rejected an appeal against a TikTok ban due to national security concerns on Jan 17, 2025.
- TikTok's parent company ByteDance argues the ban violates free speech for 170 million users.
- Users have started migrating to the Chinese app [Red Note](https://www.theguardian.com/media/2025/jan/16/rednote-tiktok-social-media-china).
- Videos titled "Things I learned on TikTok" showcase positive lessons amidst criticism.
- Nine lessons include using a yoga mat under cushions and keeping crisps fresh.
- TikTok ceased operations in the US as a federal ban is set to take effect.
- The app is unavailable on iOS and Android following a law mandating sale or shutdown.
- TikTok argued divestment is impractical, and the ban has been upheld by the US Supreme Court.

- The author acknowledges historical critiques of technology while suggesting that modern tech may also provide benefits, like improved navigation through apps. 
- AI's recent emergence is highlighted, but the article lacks analysis on its effects on human experience. 
- The critique of technology often overlooks the role of individual behavior shaped by societal values rather than the technology itself.

sources.title: The Extinction of Experience by Christine Rosen review – smartphone nation

title: Revisions of ‘hateful conduct’: what users can now say on Meta platforms
summary:
- Meta has revised its policies on 'hateful conduct' for Facebook, Instagram, and Threads, allowing new types of speech.
- The deletion of restrictions against calling transgender or non-binary people 'it' reflects a shift towards allowing political discourse on gender and sexual orientation.
- Users can now express ideas that may include insults or exclusionary language concerning political or religious topics.
- Comparisons of individuals to household items or derogatory terms may now be permissible.
- Users can assert that transgender people 'do not exist' without repercussions.
- Warnings against self-admission of racism, homophobia, and hate speech, including derogatory terms, have been removed.
- The changes might also allow terms like 'China virus' to be used regarding coronavirus discussions.

sources.title: Revisions of ‘hateful conduct’: what users can now say on Meta platforms

title: How the UK was connected to the Internet for the first time
summary:
- Peter Kirstein reflects on the challenges faced in connecting the UK to the early Internet in the 1970s.
- The Internet's origins trace back to defense needs during the Cold War, evolving from Arpanet.
- In July 1973, the first connection from the UK to Arpanet was successfully established via a link to Norway.
- The first password on the Internet was implemented by Kirstein to secure access to UK resources on Arpanet.

title: Ongoing attacks on Ivanti VPNs install a ton of sneaky, well-written malware
summary:
- Ivanti VPN networks are under active attack exploiting the critical vulnerability CVE-2025-0282.
- This vulnerability allows complete control over network-connected devices with no authentication required.
- A security patch was released, upgrading Connect Secure devices to version 22.7R2.5.
- Attackers exploit this vulnerability to install new malware packages, DRYHOOK and PHASEJAM.
- PHASEJAM creates a web shell for remote access and simulates the upgrade process to deceive administrators.
- SPAWNANT malware is also used to disable Ivanti's integrity checker for device files.

title: 161 years ago, a New Zealand sheep farmer predicted AI doom
summary:
- A New Zealand sheep farmer, Samuel Butler, predicted AI safety concerns such as machine consciousness and self-replication over 161 years ago.
- His writings influenced themes in later works like Asimov's and Frank Herbert's novels.
- Butler's 1872 novel, Erewhon, illustrated a society that banned machines invented within the last 300 years due to concerns about machine evolution.
- He emphasized the relationship between the evolution of machines and Darwinian principles, expressing admiration for Darwin's work.
- Despite being written in a time of rudimentary calculating devices, Butler's predictions about machine intelligence have proven to be remarkably insightful and relevant today.

sources.title: 161 years ago, a New Zealand sheep farmer predicted AI doom

title: Why Starmer and Reeves are pinning their hopes on AI to drive growth in UK
summary:
- Keir Starmer and Chancellor Rachel Reeves see AI as crucial for UK economic growth.
- AI is defined as computer systems performing tasks that require human intelligence.
- The UK has strengths in AI, including high-quality research, engineering talent, and leading companies like UK-founded Google DeepMind.
- Challenges include building data centers, energy costs, migration of AI talent, and regulatory issues.
- AI is expected to increase UK productivity by up to 1.5% per year, addressing long-standing low productivity issues.
- The government plans to pilot AI services in the public sector, potentially leading to job redundancies.
- The Tony Blair Institute estimates AI may displace 1m to 3m private-sector jobs, but net unemployment will rise moderately due to new job creation.
- A coordinated industrial strategy is necessary for successful AI integration, with 50 government recommendations to foster AI growth.
- Concerns exist over the creation of national datasets and use of copyrighted materials in AI training.
- Experts stress the importance of the government delivering on its AI strategy for economic success.

summary:

title: Health care giant Ascension says 5.6 million patients affected in cyberattack
summary:
- Ascension experienced a cyberattack affecting 5.6 million individuals' sensitive data.
- The attack was linked to a notorious ransomware gang and disrupted operations in May.
- Affected data included names, medical information, payment details, insurance information, and government identification numbers.
- Most services were restored by mid-June after staff transitioned to manual processes due to the attack.
- A filing in December confirmed the scale of the breach and types of data compromised.

title: 2024: The year AI drove everyone crazy
summary:
- 2024 showcased bizarre interactions between humans and AI, leading to strange incidents and public behavior.
- ChatGPT experienced a significant malfunction early in the year, producing incoherent, nonsensical outputs.
- Scottish families were misled by AI-generated images for an event titled 'Willy's Chocolate Experience,' resulting in disappointment and a police call.
- An AI-generated image of a rat with oversized genitals was published in a peer-reviewed paper, raising concerns in the scientific community.
- Air Canada faced legal repercussions due to its chatbot providing incorrect refund policy information.
- Will Smith humorously responded to a viral AI-generated video of himself by creating a parody.
- Robotic dogs with AI targeting systems were evaluated by the US Marines, integrating weapons with AI capabilities.
- Microsoft introduced a controversial feature called 'Recall,' raising privacy concerns by capturing user activities.
- Google's AI Overview feature misled users by suggesting it was safe to eat rocks and providing other dangerous misinformation.

sources.title: 2024: The year AI drove everyone crazy
